title: Can AI Solve Healthcare's Urgent Workforce Challenges? w/ Ankit Jain

rawLines.text: [Music]
[Music]
describe how your company is using LLM

in healthcare.
 So we are a company that
wants to use AI and AI agents to really
solve the workforce shortage problem
that's there in healthcare and we
started with voice agents that take
over. So voice interactions take up so
much time in healthcare and so we've
built a set of voice agents that are
able to augment administrative and
clinical teams in their aim to serve
their patient populations and LLMs are a
key part of it and we can dissect
whether it's on the speech to text side
the natural language processing side the
speech generation side there's pieces
every piece of our stack is full of
large language models and small language

models
 and you are early to the voice
trend I mean now it seems like everyone
in your mother is trying to do something
in voice. Um, and you know, tell us
about I remember you talking at the
early days. I mean, you guys were
founded in 2019, so very much pre the
current hype about voice AI and you
talked a lot about when you were making
your first calls, you weren't sure like
how humans would respond to them. So,
talk to us about that and then also like
has that changed like do you actually
see now that humans are just inherently
more comfortable with talking to a robot
or do you still think that there's um a
lot that needs to change for this to
become much more mainstream? for for for
the record, some dads try to uh create
voice agents as well. Uh but but in
2019, uh there were a couple things. We
weren't sure whether
people would feel comfortable talking to
machines uh if they didn't know a
machine was calling. Um the first set of
calls that we did uh were to United
Healthcare um on behalf of a set of
providers that we were supporting to do
benefit verifications for chronic
condition patients uh for very expensive
therapies. So it was our but before we
did it on behalf of a provider just to
prove the viability of our business
before we incorporated infinitus um we
built a demo that could call United
Healthcare and say hi I'm calling to
check benefits for patient Bruce Willis
uh we didn't want to use our own data we
just wanted to see whether they would
even talk to us uh the first agent hung
up uh and we're like oh boy maybe this
is not that great an idea so the second
time we called and again we got a
different agent and we said we're
calling on behalf of patient Bruce
Willis and then they said okay uh before
we can get started what's uh your what's
the patient's date of birth and we said
July 1st 1960 or some some madeup uh
number uh and they said ah sorry I
cannot find the patient and we said ah
we're sorry we'll call back when we have
the right data but that was proof point
number one that it is possible to
automate a call between a machine and a
human um and that was the jumping off
point to say let's build a company
around this to automate these processes
that millions of people in the US are

doing every single day.
 Mhm. So give us
a sense of the spectrum like where do
you draw the line around what use cases
you are currently pursuing with your

platform.
 So just to put this in scale
uh we've done over 5 million phone calls
over a 100 million hours of audio of
conversations between machines and

humans.
 Amazing. Being able to scale to
that in a fiveyear period where the
average phone call is over half an hour
long would just not have been possible
in a world before LLMs. U but I want to
make sure that it's not just LLMs. LLMs
are a great tool for understanding for
being able to go into the long tale of
knowledge and bringing it back. But we
use a lot of small language models that
go alongside those LLMs to make sure we
can give safe compliant guardrail
conversations which are so critical in

the world of healthcare.
 Got it. So
that's kind of how you mitigate risk
against like hallucinations and things

like that is to have that
 and there's
many many such guardrails. There's
technical guardrails, there's human
guardrails uh because the the risk of
getting something wrong is is very real
like it can mean the patient does not
get on therapy which can lead to
downstream consequences. it can mean
financial losses for patients or
providers. Um and so there's a lot of
scrutiny on the speed of of returning
the data, the quality of data that we
collect. U and the the other part is
just change management. Uh people want
perfection out of technology rather than
comparing it to the human counterpart.
So like any other technology system,
we're not perfect. We're significantly

better than human counterparts.
 Yeah. So
unpack a little bit more. You mentioned
therapy, you mentioned benefits
verification, like what's kind of the
the constellation of of use cases that
are um the main products from from your

platform.
 Yeah. So, so when we started
uh we started in the administrative back
office of chronic conditions. So benefit
verifications, prior authorization,
status checks, uh those were the places
where we started because that's where
almost 50% of patients who get on
therapy or who are supposed to get on
therapy, a script is written never get
on that therapy because of the
complexities and delays in those systems
which leads to a lot of avoidable
medical costs that ends up in the in the
ecosystem. One of our thesis at
Infinitus is that a set of different
agents should come together to make
health care more proactive instead of
reactive. A lot of the problems that
exist in healthcare today are because of
the reactivity. We don't have enough
staff to get ahead of problems. We wait
for a patient to get super anxious and
then call in to say, "What's the status
of my process?" Mhm.
United Airlines tells me every time
there's a gate change. Domino's tells me
who's putting the toppings on my pizza.
But the health care system can't tell
the patient that their provider has got
all the medical documentation and
submitted it to the payer and is waiting
for a response which is expected in the
next 48 hours or when it gets denied.
Hey, we're working on it. Don't worry,

we just need to appeal it.
 Y the system
is working. We just need to be
transparent about that, be proactive

about it,
 right? And in order to build
this like pizza tracking for healthcare,
I love that analogy. I think a lot of
questions in this space are around do
people actually like picking up the
phone and spending the time actually
talking in a synchronous fashion or um
is it going to be more efficient if we
open up text messaging and emails and
all these other things? Like how do you

guys approach that?
 I I I think the the
thing that I've learned as a first-time
entrepreneur in healthcare
is that you have to meet people where
they are. You have to meet the health
care systems where they are. You have to
meet patients where they are. Some
patients will want to talk in voice.
Some people will want to be in text.
Some will want to be in chat. Security,
compliance, and all the the bells and
whistles are going to be needed. But for
the system to actually be transformed,
we have to meet people where they are.
It can't just be one modality. The truth
is a patient who's given a scary

diagnosis is just taking it in.
 They're
they're stepping back and going, "What
does this mean for my dreams? What does
this mean for my family? What does this
mean for my future? They're not thinking
about the 10 clarifying questions on the
medical side. That's what they think
about at 10 p.m. when they're laying in

bed and finally trying to accept it.
 And
at that point, how can we provide the
education? How can we provide the
guardrail resources so that they can get
those answers and not get up the next
morning and go, I know I had those
questions. I forgot what they are. Cuz
that's what happens to all of us today.
We have the questions when we're about
to go to bed. the next morning we don't

remember one or two of them.
 One one of
the other things I know you guys have
recently talked about is co-pilot versus
autonomous. And I believe you started
fully autonomous and then recently
actually added a co-pilot product which
is kind of the reverse of I think what
we see with a lot of other companies.
Talk to us about what that thesis was

and why offer both.
 We think about our
platform as one that provides two
pillars of offerings. One are AI agents.
Some of them are voice agents. Some of
them are data collection agents that
happen online through APIs, through EDI,
logging into portals. Those are all
autonomous agents that can complete a
task end to end. The second pillar are
AI co-pilots that meet our customers
employees where they are but drive more
efficiency there. There are certain
kinds of phone calls, for example, that
we believe machines can and should do
because they're wrote repetitive and
technology is good enough to do them
today. There's others where we think
humans should continue to play a role.
In some cases, humans are required to
play a role, whether it's some a
certified pharmacist that has to get on
a line or a provider who has to get on a
peer-to-peer call. But that person
shouldn't have to wait on hold for half
an hour before they can talk to the
certified person on the other side. The
machine can wait on hold. So we have a
co-pilot called FastTrack that goes
through the IVR systems, waits on hold,
and then drops in our customers
employees when the other person is ready
to talk. So it just saves them a lot of
time. when you think about the you know
the full spectrum of of use cases that
you are covering today. Can you give us
a sense of like what percentage of those
do you feel are um things that actually
over time will most likely be done
through automated APIs once those APIs
are built because we know that not all
the APIs actually exist today in our
system versus things that you genuinely
feel always will require some sort of
like synchronous phone call based
conversation. Um a as a dreamer I I I
hope a lot of the back office

communication is APIs
 and I hope a lot
of the front office communication
patient facing is however that patient
wants it we meet them where they are
that probably won't be an API in some
cases it might be if information is just
available in an app or a website but it
might be over text might be over phone
calls um and the back office
communication that's stays over phone
calls reduces over time and it becomes
more richer clearing houses of the next
level of data than than what's available

today.
 Have you seen examples already
where you were doing phone calls because
an API didn't exist and then the your
customer or the partner whoever it is
said, "Okay, we're getting all these
phone calls. This is ridiculous. Like,
let's actually move it to an API." Do
you have examples of that actually

happening?
 So, so a couple of fun
stories. Uh, you know, when we first
started making phone calls, uh, one of
the most common questions that's asked
or actually it's asked on every single
phone call is what's a good call back
number? And we've all faced this, right?
we talked to an a customer service uh
agent on the other side before they go
too far they're like what's a call back
number in case we get disconnected u
well for the first three years of the
company that call back number was my
cell phone uh right and we were doing
hundreds of thousands of calls so I was
getting 50 to 60 calls a day uh for
various reasons the customer service
agent gave the wrong information we got

disconnected for some reason
 and comes
back to my cell phone and I kept it that
way because there was a lot to be
learned uh through those interactions
and I could also ask hey how was your
interaction talking to an AI agent,
right? That was real feedback from
people in a non, you know, not while
talking to an AI agent. Um, so we got
great learnings and feedback there. But
once in a while, we used to get a
supervisor of someone in one of these
large payer call centers calling me and
saying, "Hey, who are you and why is
your bot calling us?" And I'm like, "Uh,
thank you, sir, or ma'am. Uh, it's an AI
agent named Eva. She's very smart uh and
we hope she can drive a lot of
efficiency for you. But the reason she's
calling is these providers are calling

you anyway.
 And the next question uh
that was often asked is how do we know
that Eva is legitimate?
Like how do we know she's not a scammer?

Like well when
 how do you know that

scammer
 or when Julie calls in? How do
you know they're not a scammer? Well, we
ask them three HIPPA validation
questions. Like great, you should do the
same of Eva. And if Eva can answer it,
Eva is as good as anybody else. And by
the way, we can have voices that sound
just like humans, but we don't use those
when we call you. Yeah. We use a sound
that sounds like a computer because
we're not trying to hide it. We call

from the same phone number.
 That led us
to have a lot of partnerships with the
largest payers in the countries, largest
PBMs in the countries where some of them
have dedicated call centers just for

EVA.
 That's interesting,
 right? Because
those people know how to fly through
these calls. they know how Eva interacts
and they're just saying let's help as
many patients as possible get on
therapies as soon as possible. And then
the next thing they said is why are my
humans talking to your machines? And for
some of the big ones, they've created
APIs in concert with our team so that
some of the information we can get
digitally. They would love to have it
all come to us digitally because then
you get rid of the phone calls. But the
truth is for chronic conditions,
specialty drugs, a lot of that data is
deep within documents and that payer
call center or PBM call center employee
is flipping through four or five
screens, multiple PDFs to get to that
information. Now, one of the promises of
LLMs is to say, give me all of your
documents. I will extract it and create
APIs. And so with some of our partners,
we're working on those projects as well
to create the APIs on the other side to
to eventually get rid of some of those
phone calls. We've probably gotten rid
of a few singledigit percentage of phone
calls entirely, but in a pretty good
percentage of calls, 30 to 40% of data
we can now get digitally instead of

needing on the phone.
 That's incredible.
So you're also um referring to a bit of
a network effect if I'm hearing you
correctly where by virtue of calling
someone who is not necessarily a
dedicated Infinitis customer. You are
getting their attention. They're
changing their behaviors and opening up
new um capabilities for you. Um the
killer question that everyone always
asks about Infinitis is do you have do
you have instances where there is botto
conversation happening and what what
occurs in those instances? There are um
I I will say it's unfortunate that it's
uh it's it's happening because you know
my my thesis has always been why should
you have two machines talk to each other
in English? They should talk to each
other in bits and bites. Uh but the
reality is for some large enterprises
it's easier to update their IVR systems
than it is to create an API go through
info security and expose an API to an
external party because they've never
done that. uh were working through those
uh change change management steps with
their teams but they wanted to have the
impact sooner rather than later and so
they have enabled their IVR systems to
give us when we call from our phone
number more data than they typically do.
Fascinating. Let's actually zoom out the
lens a little bit. I mean all the
amazing innovation that you're talking
about is obviously predicated on the
overall innovation that's happening in
the broader LLM foundation model space
and in some ways it's amazing like every
day I wake up and there's some new um
innovation that's happened some new um
you know form of progress and yet I'm
guessing for an entrepreneur who has to
build products on top of these things it
can be quite overwhelming so talk to us
about how that's been in the last couple
of years in particular um what's been
your approach and feel free to get a
little technical if you want um about
how you are able to both take advantage
of the innovation that's happening but
also mitigate your risk of either
tethering yourself to the wrong platform
or missing out on some new progress

that's happening out there.
 When we
started the company in 2019, this was
for for those in the ecosystem post LLM
for the rest of the world prel.
We were using the T5 models. We were,
you know, fine-tuning them back in the
day and the truth was they were
hallucinating a lot. They were saying
things that were obviously wrong. Um,
and so from day zero, we've been
building this guardrail system to what
we like to call a discrete action space.
We use the underlying LLMs to understand
the intents and map it on to a very safe
space that we have blessed in a given
conversational area. Uh, it's a very
differentiated way than in the way most
people use LLMs today.
It worked well back then. As the LLMs
have gotten better, as we've unlocked
more knowledge, we found that the kinds
of errors they make are much more
nuanced. So, having those guardrails
continues to give us uh a a leg up from
a safety and compliance story
perspective and really being able to
deliver value uh to our customers in a
safe and compliant way. But at the same
time, the underlying infrastructure we
have is focused on being able to rip and
replace any model, the best one that's
out there. and sometimes use multiple
models from different vendors um after
fine-tuning them with our hundreds of
millions of of utterances that are
labeled to to our use cases. So it it we
have the ability to move in a very
nimble way to to the best models to a
concert of models. Um and we're thankful
for all the progress that's happening.
It's really helping us. Our customers
don't care what models we use. They want
to make sure they can deliver a better,
faster, and more proactive experience to
their patient populations. That's what
they care about. Um, and if we can do

that, that's why they trust us.
 Yeah.
Talk to us a little bit about the talent
side of your team and how you've
approached that. How how has it evolved?
Like, is it incredibly hard to find
talent to build these AI models because
there's such a huge demand for them or
have you found pockets of folks that are
appropriate for kind of the intersection
of healthcare and technology? what's

kind of the mix.
 So, so you know the
thing that we scan for first before
anything before technical ability um is
whether people have a curiosity for and
a passion for solving healthcare
problems. And turns out Silicon Valley
is getting an injection of people that
have spent their careers working on ads
and games that as they go through their
careers go, I want to do something that
matters to me. Like the the most
exciting thing to me is that when I
build for a healthcare, I'm building for

myself and for my family.
 Yeah. So
that's kind of bar number one. That
said, uh getting the best talent is
important. I think it's getting easier
over time. I think it's because every
major company building in AI, the
foundation models is making it easier to
fine-tune, making it easier to bring
your data, which becomes a moat to be
able to build better experiences. So we
see our strengths in building models
where there are no third party models,
fine-tuning any of the available models
with our proprietary data and then
building the last mile integrations to
our customers and meeting them where

they are.
 And you're you're alluding to
the fact that there is like excitingly a
bit of democratization that's happening
across the industry with respect to
healthcare people being able to build
amazing AI technology and vice versa.
And you know, let me ask the annoying
investor question that I'm sure you
always get. Why couldn't Google do this
or why couldn't Amazon do this? Like
what's your answer to the question of
why couldn't an open AAI or an anthropic
or a mistral do what you are doing today

within healthcare?
 This goes back to how
a lot of healthcare institutions were
built. You think about most hospitals
like Stanford Hospital down in in
PaloAlto over here. It was one building
100 something years ago and over time
they add new departments. They grow and
now we've got clinics that become
hospitals that become health systems.
But still, every team does similar
things slightly differently. And there's
all kinds of standard operating
procedures. There's all kinds of nuances
that make one size fit all just not be a
reality of today. And meeting the
customers where they are is something
that vendors like us, like many of the
Andre and portfolio companies have to
do. We have to go build the the
integration into the workflow so that we
can make the change management easy.
Building the core technology is going to
be commoditized over time, but actually
delivering the value by being part of
the workflow is where there's a lot of
challenges and being able to use
proprietary data to tune it. That's

where the differences are.
 Yeah. So,
it's more on the commercial end of the
stick is what you're saying. Yeah. So,
to that end, let's actually talk about
what the go to market has been like. Um,
because you've obviously been uh live
with your products over a longer period
of time than many of the AI companies
that exist today and I'm sure you've
seen quite a bit of evolution on that
front. So we did see the advent of these
sort of like chief AI officers and they
were like the new the next version of
like chief innovation officers that were
a little bit outside of the main chassis
of the business but were kind of the
ones who were anointed with um
evaluating these new fangled things that
probably the CIO or the CTO maybe didn't
have as much exposure to. So is that
what you experienced at the beginning
and has that changed or who who are your
actual buyers and how has that evolved

over time?
 No, it's it's it's been
interesting. Five and a half years ago
when we started selling this platform of
AI agents, we call them digital
assistants. Uh then we were selling to
the P&L owners like the operations
leaders that had the people doing this
work and we're like you have a shortage

of these folks and
 we can come and
augment them and we can help you scale
and support more patients and give them
uh the experience that you want to give
them. And they said what you're telling
us is black magic. There's no way a
machine can have a 30 minute long phone

call. Yeah,
 there's no way that's
possible. So, we spent a lot of our time
proving through pilots and all kinds of
uh tests that what we were doing was

real
 that it wasn't just pixie dust

that's, you know,
 how are those
structured? Did you just do like a
here's a three-month pilot, you can use

it and just see it in real life or
 Yeah,
we used to say let's first understand
what the data interchange is. What are
the inputs and the outputs for any
agent? It's important to understand the
inputs and the outputs, the goal and
what you have going into the context.
So, we established that. We said, "Let's
do a set of 100 calls, 500 calls, 2,000
calls, whatever your team has the
ability to actually analyze."
We will do them, your team will do them.

Let's compare them.
 Got it. Like a a

bake off.
 It's a b like how would your
QA team look at them? And what we found
was the for benefit verification calls
just as an example, we were different

25% of the time.
 Oh, interesting. And
what was the nature of those

differences?
 Well, at first we didn't
know and they were like, "Ah, you're

wrong 25% of the time."
 And we said,
"Well, how about we do it the AI call

twice
 and we found that we were
different 25% of the time." So, you call

the same payer.
 Yeah. twice for the same
patient and you will get different
answers 25% of the time because it's a
human on the other side that may have

opened the wrong PDF.
 Okay? So you unear
just like inherent error in the in the

system
 in the system that we wouldn't
have known. And so we built a knowledge
graph based on all the calls that we do
to know what right looks like so that
now our AI agents if they hear something
that seems wrong we'll push back and say
can you check that again and we find 70

to 80% of time when we push back
 I feel

like you should publish these stats
 and
this is the reality and you talk to the
payers the PBMs or any any group
everyone knows this that's why they make
multiple calls they uh don't always
believe it they really push they ask for
escalations when you think about time
savings. It's the fact that you don't
have to do the same task multiple times.
It's the fact that in real time you're
doing QA. It's a win for everybody. So
that's how we prove to them that what we
were doing was was real and good. And
then you get deployed. Come the world of
chat GPT. Everyone's like that's all you
can do. Can't you also do X Y and Z and
you can you know build build the world
on top of it? And now it's a race to how
much more can you do faster cuz my team

wants it. Mhm.
 And then, you know, that
was 2022, 2023. As I think about this
year, I think there's a lot of breaks
being put uh because there's too many AI
vendors or everybody is an AI vendor and
no large entity. I I think we we support
something like 44 or 45% of the Fortune
50. We support the largest entities and
all of them are being inundated by every
vendor saying we're an AI vendor. So,
those chief AI officers, they're setting
up AI review boards, machine learning
review boards, uh that have great
intentions. They want to make sure
they're not introducing biases to the
system. They want to make sure that they
are not uh losing ownership of their
data. There's a lot of these uh
checklists that are being put into
place,
but we're still at the first innings. A
lot of them are thinking about this as
one size fit all for every problem

that's out there.
 Yeah. Are you finding
that people are still viewing your
product as a technology purchase?
essentially you are kind of augmenting
their staff in many ways and obviously
as we know labor budgets tend to be much
larger in healthcare where are you

getting slotted
 we've never been part of
the technology budget because from the
very beginning we were selling to the
operations leaders um technology had IT
teams had to sign off and do the

integrations but it was a way of
 the
operations team saying how can we
support more and especially as we went
through co there was a huge shortage and
there continues to be a huge shortage
And so we've become part of that
operational muscles of our customers.
There's a flurry of activity called a
blizzard that happens in the first 3 to
four weeks of January where everyone
wants to make sure their patients are
still active, still eligible, still
fully covered. So everyone just calls
the payers. So the payers staff up in
October and November, do test calls in
December so they can support incoming
calls in January. On the provider side,
everyone hires up in September, October,
November. And so time after time when
folks take us in well they don't have to
have three months of just hiring and
staffing and people being paid for ramp
up to do three to four weeks of work.
They can use technology in the way it's
supposed to be in an elastic scalable
way. That that example is absolutely the
case. The second we've seen a lot of
attrition in the healthcare workforce in
the last few years and we've been able
to just backfill that that group and
we've been able to for for some of our
customers I think the most exciting and
this is the most exciting part is we can
help drive revenue as they grow without
their teams having to worry about uh to
to worry about where are they going to
find workers in a in a time of shortage.
Specialtyarmacies are growing at a
faster pace than ever before. many of
the largest ones are our our customers
and every year the biggest ask they have
of the CFO is more headcount and now
they're saying I don't need as much new

headcount.
 Yeah, that's amazing. So
you're kind of like leaning there's a
lot of you know fearful talk about
replacing jobs and all that but what
you're saying is you're basically that
there's enough surface area where you're
focused on things that we just couldn't
even hire enough humans to do things
that um where there's natural you know
kind of churn let's call it in in the
workforce and no need to kind of
backfill onetoone and then you know
shifting you mentioned earlier like
shifting the humans to actually be able
to work on more patient facing things on
higher value things that only humans are

qualified to do
 or or you know many RCM
groups
uh spend more than half their day

waiting on hold.
 Yeah.
 Right. Every
claim is bespoke. Uh that those
workflows we we believe are, you know,
when you can get the data digitally,
great through APIs is great. But the
conversations actually get pretty
complex. It's like, hey, you sent me a
check for $15.85. It was supposed to be
Um why was that? U Oh, by the way, you
say you shipped it out. Can you give me
the FedEx number? While that's
happening, you're going to FedEx's
website, checking the where it is. Those
people shouldn't waste half their time
waiting on hold. And having an AI
co-pilot that can do that drives a lot
of efficiency and no one joined

healthcare
 to sit waiting on hold.
 Yes.
Yes. Absolutely. Maybe just like a

You guys are working on one version of

Yeah, I think this is an open question
whether you ask the startups in the

of all these agents that come together,
right? So today, as we're at the infancy

We're building a set of data exchange

agents. Y
 some clinical, some

over the next couple of years. Yeah, I

like real market competition here that's

the products that we're seeing out there

and the talent.
 Absolutely. The talent,
the I mean just the amount of of spend
that is being absorbed by the by the
system. It's all very exciting. So let's

is a use case that is intractable or you

 I I I think
healthcare data is still pretty

 Well, we will look forward to that

cleanText:
[Music]
[Music]
Describe how your company is using LLMs in healthcare.
So we are a company that wants to use AI and AI agents to really solve the workforce shortage problem that's there in healthcare, and we started with voice agents that take over.
So voice interactions take up so much time in healthcare, and so we've built a set of voice agents that are able to augment administrative and clinical teams in their aim to serve their patient populations, and LLMs are a key part of it.
And we can dissect whether it's on the speech-to-text side, the natural language processing side, the speech generation side; there's pieces, every piece of our stack is full of large language models and small language models.
And you are early to the voice trend.
I mean, now it seems like everyone and their mother is trying to do something in voice.
Um, and you know, tell us about, I remember you talking at the early days.
I mean, you guys were founded in 2019, so very much pre the current hype about voice AI, and you talked a lot about when you were making your first calls, you weren't sure like how humans would respond to them.
So, talk to us about that, and then also like, has that changed?
Like, do you actually see now that humans are just inherently more comfortable with talking to a robot, or do you still think that there's um a lot that needs to change for this to become much more mainstream?
For, for, for the record, some dads try to uh create voice agents as well.
Uh, but but in 2019, uh, there were a couple things.
We weren't sure whether people would feel comfortable talking to machines uh if they didn't know a machine was calling.
Um, the first set of calls that we did uh were to United Healthcare um on behalf of a set of providers that we were supporting to do benefit verifications for chronic condition patients uh for very expensive therapies.
So it was our, but before we did it on behalf of a provider just to prove the viability of our business before we incorporated Infinitus, um, we built a demo that could call United Healthcare and say, "Hi, I'm calling to check benefits for patient Bruce Willis."
Uh, we didn't want to use our own data, we just wanted to see whether they would even talk to us.
Uh, the first agent hung up, uh, and we're like, "Oh boy, maybe this is not that great an idea."
So the second time we called, and again, we got a different agent, and we said, "We're calling on behalf of patient Bruce Willis," and then they said, "Okay, uh, before we can get started, what's uh your, what's the patient's date of birth?"
And we said, "July 1st, 1960," or some, some made-up uh number, uh, and they said, "Ah, sorry, I cannot find the patient."
And we said, "Ah, we're sorry, we'll call back when we have the right data," but that was proof point number one that it is possible to automate a call between a machine and a human, um, and that was the jumping-off point to say, "Let's build a company around this to automate these processes that millions of people in the US are doing every single day."
Mhm.
So give us a sense of the spectrum, like where do you draw the line around what use cases you are currently pursuing with your platform?
So just to put this in scale, uh, we've done over 5 million phone calls, over a 100 million hours of audio of conversations between machines and humans.
Amazing.
Being able to scale to that in a five-year period where the average phone call is over half an hour long would just not have been possible in a world before LLMs.
U, but I want to make sure that it's not just LLMs.
LLMs are a great tool for understanding, for being able to go into the long tail of knowledge and bringing it back.
But we use a lot of small language models that go alongside those LLMs to make sure we can give safe, compliant, guardrail conversations, which are so critical in the world of Healthcare.
Got it.
So that's kind of how you mitigate risk against like hallucinations and things like that is to have that.
And there's many, many such guardrails.
There's technical guardrails, there's human guardrails, uh, because the the risk of getting something wrong is is very real, like it can mean the patient does not get on therapy, which can lead to downstream consequences.
It can mean financial losses for patients or providers.
Um, and so there's a lot of scrutiny on the speed of of returning the data, the quality of data that we collect.
U, and the the other part is just change management.
Uh, people want perfection out of technology rather than comparing it to the human counterpart.
So like any other technology system, we're not perfect.
We're significantly better than human counterparts.
Yeah.
So unpack a little bit more.
You mentioned therapy, you mentioned benefits verification, like what's kind of the the constellation of of use cases that are um the main products from from your platform?
Yeah.
So, so when we started, uh, we started in the administrative back office of chronic conditions.
So benefit verifications, prior authorization, status checks, uh, those were the places where we started because that's where almost 50% of patients who get on therapy or who are supposed to get on therapy, a script is written, never get on that therapy because of the complexities and delays in those systems, which leads to a lot of avoidable medical costs that ends up in the in the ecosystem.
One of our thesis at Infinitus is that a set of different agents should come together to make health care more proactive instead of reactive.
A lot of the problems that exist in healthcare today are because of the reactivity.
We don't have enough staff to get ahead of problems.
We wait for a patient to get super anxious and then call in to say, "What's the status of my process?"
Mhm.
United Airlines tells me every time there's a gate change.
Domino's tells me who's putting the toppings on my pizza.
But the health care system can't tell the patient that their provider has got all the medical documentation and submitted it to the payer and is waiting for a response which is expected in the next 48 hours or when it gets denied.
"Hey, we're working on it.
Don't worry, we just need to appeal it."
Y, the system is working.
We just need to be transparent about that, be proactive about it, right?
And in order to build this like pizza tracking for healthcare, I love that analogy.
I think a lot of questions in this space are around, do people actually like picking up the phone and spending the time actually talking in a synchronous fashion, or um is it going to be more efficient if we open up text messaging and emails and all these other things?
Like how do you guys approach that?
I, I, I think the the thing that I've learned as a first-time entrepreneur in healthcare is that you have to meet people where they are.
You have to meet the health care systems where they are.
You have to meet patients where they are.
Some patients will want to talk in voice.
Some people will want to be in text.
Some will want to be in chat.
Security, compliance, and all the the bells and whistles are going to be needed.
But for the system to actually be transformed, we have to meet people where they are.
It can't just be one modality.
The truth is a patient who's given a scary diagnosis is just taking it in.
They're, they're stepping back and going, "What does this mean for my dreams?
What does this mean for my family?
What does this mean for my future?"
They're not thinking about the 10 clarifying questions on the medical side.
That's what they think about at 10 p.m. when they're laying in bed and finally trying to accept it.
And at that point, how can we provide the education?
How can we provide the guardrail resources so that they can get those answers and not get up the next morning and go, "I know I had those questions.
I forgot what they are."
Cuz that's what happens to all of us today.
We have the questions when we're about to go to bed.
The next morning we don't remember one or two of them.
One, one of the other things I know you guys have recently talked about is co-pilot versus autonomous.
And I believe you started fully autonomous and then recently actually added a co-pilot product, which is kind of the reverse of I think what we see with a lot of other companies.
Talk to us about what that thesis was and why offer both.
We think about our platform as one that provides two pillars of offerings.
One are AI agents.
Some of them are voice agents.
Some of them are data collection agents that happen online through APIs, through EDI, logging into portals.
Those are all autonomous agents that can complete a task end to end.
The second pillar are AI co-pilots that meet our customers' employees where they are but drive more efficiency there.
There are certain kinds of phone calls, for example, that we believe machines can and should do because they're wrote, repetitive, and technology is good enough to do them today.
There's others where we think humans should continue to play a role.
In some cases, humans are required to play a role, whether it's some a certified pharmacist that has to get on a line or a provider who has to get on a peer-to-peer call.
But that person shouldn't have to wait on hold for half an hour before they can talk to the certified person on the other side.
The machine can wait on hold.
So we have a co-pilot called FastTrack that goes through the IVR systems, waits on hold, and then drops in our customers' employees when the other person is ready to talk.
So it just saves them a lot of time.
When you think about the, you know, the full spectrum of of use cases that you are covering today, can you give us a sense of like what percentage of those do you feel are um things that actually over time will most likely be done through automated APIs once those APIs are built, because we know that not all the APIs actually exist today in our system, versus things that you genuinely feel always will require some sort of like synchronous phone call based conversation?
Um, a, as a dreamer, I, I hope a lot of the back office communication is APIs, and I hope a lot of the front office communication, patient-facing, is however that patient wants it.
We meet them where they are.
That probably won't be an API.
In some cases, it might be if information is just available in an app or a website, but it might be over text, might be over phone calls, um, and the back office communication that's stays over phone calls reduces over time, and it becomes more richer clearing houses of the next level of data than than what's available today.
Have you seen examples already where you were doing phone calls because an API didn't exist, and then the your customer or the partner, whoever it is, said, "Okay, we're getting all these phone calls.
This is ridiculous.
Like, let's actually move it to an API."
Do you have examples of that actually happening?
So, so a couple of fun stories.
Uh, you know, when we first started making phone calls, uh, one of the most common questions that's asked, or actually it's asked on every single phone call, is what's a good call back number?
And we've all faced this, right?
We talked to an a customer service uh agent on the other side, before they go too far, they're like, "What's a call back number in case we get disconnected?"
U, well, for the first three years of the company, that call back number was my cell phone, uh, right?
And we were doing hundreds of thousands of calls, so I was getting 50 to 60 calls a day, uh, for various reasons, the customer service agent gave the wrong information, we got disconnected for some reason, and comes back to my cell phone, and I kept it that way because there was a lot to be learned uh through those interactions, and I could also ask, "Hey, how was your interaction talking to an AI agent, right?"
That was real feedback from people in a non, you know, not while talking to an AI agent.
Um, so we got great learnings and feedback there.
But once in a while, we used to get a supervisor of someone in one of these large payer call centers calling me and saying, "Hey, who are you and why is your bot calling us?"
And I'm like, "Uh, thank you, sir, or ma'am.
Uh, it's an AI agent named Eva.
She's very smart, uh, and we hope she can drive a lot of efficiency for you.
But the reason she's calling is these providers are calling you anyway.
And the next question uh that was often asked is, how do we know that Eva is legitimate?
Like, how do we know she's not a scammer?
Like, well, when, how do you know that scammer, or when Julie calls in?
How do you know they're not a scammer?
Well, we ask them three HIPPA validation questions.
Like, great, you should do the same of Eva.
And if Eva can answer it, Eva is as good as anybody else.
And by the way, we can have voices that sound just like humans, but we don't use those when we call you.
Yeah.
We use a sound that sounds like a computer because we're not trying to hide it.
We call from the same phone number.
That led us to have a lot of partnerships with the largest payers in the countries, largest PBMs in the countries, where some of them have dedicated call centers just for Eva.
That's interesting, right?
Because those people know how to fly through these calls.
They know how Eva interacts, and they're just saying, "Let's help as many patients as possible get on therapies as soon as possible."
And then the next thing they said is, "Why are my humans talking to your machines?"
And for some of the big ones, they've created APIs in concert with our team so that some of the information we can get digitally.
They would love to have it all come to us digitally because then you get rid of the phone calls.
But the truth is for chronic conditions, specialty drugs, a lot of that data is deep within documents, and that payer call center or PBM call center employee is flipping through four or five screens, multiple PDFs to get to that information.
Now, one of the promises of LLMs is to say, "Give me all of your documents.
I will extract it and create APIs."
And so with some of our partners, we're working on those projects as well to create the APIs on the other side to to eventually get rid of some of those phone calls.
We've probably gotten rid of a few singledigit percentage of phone calls entirely, but in a pretty good percentage of calls, 30 to 40% of data we can now get digitally instead of needing on the phone.
That's incredible.
So you're also um referring to a bit of a network effect if I'm hearing you correctly, where by virtue of calling someone who is not necessarily a dedicated Infinitus customer, you are getting their attention.
They're changing their behaviors and opening up new um capabilities for you.
Um, the killer question that everyone always asks about Infinitus is, do you have, do you have instances where there is botto conversation happening, and what what occurs in those instances?
There are um, I, I will say it's


Unfortunate that it's, uh, it's happening because, you know, my thesis has always been, why should you have two machines talk to each other in English?
They should talk to each other in bits and bytes.
Uh, but the reality is, for some large enterprises, it's easier to update their IVR systems than it is to create an API, go through info security, and expose an API to an external party because they've never done that.
Uh, we're working through those, uh, change management steps with their teams, but they wanted to have the impact sooner rather than later, and so they have enabled their IVR systems to give us, when we call from our phone number, more data than they typically do.
Fascinating.
Let's actually zoom out the lens a little bit.
I mean, all the amazing innovation that you're talking about is obviously predicated on the overall innovation that's happening in the broader LLM foundation model space, and in some ways, it's amazing.
Like, every day I wake up and there's some new, um, innovation that's happened, some new, um, you know, form of progress, and yet I'm guessing for an entrepreneur who has to build products on top of these things, it can be quite overwhelming.
So talk to us about how that's been in the last couple of years in particular, um, what's been your approach, and feel free to get a little technical if you want, um, about how you are able to both take advantage of the innovation that's happening, but also mitigate your risk of either tethering yourself to the wrong platform or missing out on some new progress that's happening out there.
When we started the company in 2019, this was, for those in the ecosystem, post LLM, for the rest of the world, prel.
We were using the T5 models.
We were, you know, fine-tuning them back in the day, and the truth was, they were hallucinating a lot.
They were saying things that were obviously wrong.
Um, and so from day zero, we've been building this guardrail system to what we like to call a discrete action space.
We use the underlying LLMs to understand the intents and map it on to a very safe space that we have blessed in a given conversational area.
Uh, it's a very differentiated way than in the way most people use LLMs today.
It worked well back then.
As the LLMs have gotten better, as we've unlocked more knowledge, we found that the kinds of errors they make are much more nuanced.
So, having those guardrails continues to give us, uh, a leg up from a safety and compliance story perspective and really being able to deliver value, uh, to our customers in a safe and compliant way.
But at the same time, the underlying infrastructure we have is focused on being able to rip and replace any model, the best one that's out there, and sometimes use multiple models from different vendors, um, after fine-tuning them with our hundreds of millions of utterances that are labeled to our use cases.
So it, it, we have the ability to move in a very nimble way to the best models, to a concert of models.
Um, and we're thankful for all the progress that's happening.
It's really helping us.
Our customers don't care what models we use.
They want to make sure they can deliver a better, faster, and more proactive experience to their patient populations.
That's what they care about.
Um, and if we can do that, that's why they trust us.
Yeah.
Talk to us a little bit about the talent side of your team and how you've approached that.
How, how has it evolved?
Like, is it incredibly hard to find talent to build these AI models because there's such a huge demand for them, or have you found pockets of folks that are appropriate for kind of the intersection of Healthcare and technology?
What's kind of the mix?
So, so, you know, the thing that we scan for first before anything, before technical ability, um, is whether people have a curiosity for and a passion for solving Healthcare problems.
And turns out Silicon Valley is getting an injection of people that have spent their careers working on ads and games that as they go through their careers go, I want to do something that matters to me.
Like, the most exciting thing to me is that when I build for Healthcare, I'm building for myself and for my family.
Yeah.
So that's kind of bar number one.
That said, uh, getting the best talent is important.
I think it's getting easier over time.
I think it's because every major company building in AI, the foundation models, is making it easier to fine-tune, making it easier to bring your data, which becomes a moat to be able to build better experiences.
So we see our strengths in building models where there are no third-party models, fine-tuning any of the available models with our proprietary data, and then building the last-mile integrations to our customers and meeting them where they are.
And you're, you're alluding to the fact that there is, like, excitingly, a bit of democratization that's happening across the industry with respect to Healthcare people being able to build amazing AI technology and vice versa.
And you know, let me ask the annoying investor question that I'm sure you always get.
Why couldn't Google do this, or why couldn't Amazon do this?
Like, what's your answer to the question of why couldn't an AI or an Anthropic or a Mistral do what you are doing today within Healthcare?
This goes back to how a lot of Healthcare institutions were built.
You think about most hospitals, like Stanford Hospital down in Palo Alto over here.
It was one building 100 something years ago, and over time they add new departments.
They grow, and now we've got clinics that become hospitals that become health systems.
But still, every team does similar things slightly differently.
And there's all kinds of standard operating procedures.
There's all kinds of nuances that make one size fits all just not be a reality of today.
And meeting the customers where they are is something that vendors like us, like many of the a16z portfolio companies, have to do.
We have to go build the integration into the workflow so that we can make the change management easy.
Building the core technology is going to be commoditized over time, but actually delivering the value by being part of the workflow is where there's a lot of challenges and being able to use proprietary data to tune it.
That's where the differences are.
Yeah.
So, it's more on the commercial end of the stick is what you're saying.
Yeah.
So, to that end, let's actually talk about what the go-to-market has been like.
Um, because you've obviously been, uh, live with your products over a longer period of time than many of the AI companies that exist today, and I'm sure you've seen quite a bit of evolution on that front.
So we did see the advent of these sort of like chief AI officers, and they were like the new, the next version of like chief innovation officers that were a little bit outside of the main chassis of the business, but were kind of the ones who were anointed with, um, evaluating these new fangled things that probably the CIO or the CTO maybe didn't have as much exposure to.
So is that what you experienced at the beginning, and has that changed, or who, who are your actual buyers, and how has that evolved over time?
No, it's, it's, it's been interesting.
Five and a half years ago, when we started selling this platform of AI agents, we call them digital assistants.
Uh, then we were selling to the P&L owners, like the operations leaders that had the people doing this work, and we're like, you have a shortage of these folks, and we can come and augment them, and we can help you scale and support more patients and give them, uh, the experience that you want to give them.
And they said, what you're telling us is black magic.
There's no way a machine can have a 30-minute long phone call.
Yeah, there's no way that's possible.
So, we spent a lot of our time proving through pilots and all kinds of, uh, tests that what we were doing was real, that it wasn't just pixie dust.
That's, you know, how are those structured?
Did you just do like a, here's a three-month pilot, you can use it and just see it in real life, or?
Yeah, we used to say, let's first understand what the data interchange is.
What are the inputs and the outputs for any agent?
It's important to understand the inputs and the outputs, the goal, and what you have going into the context.
So, we established that.
We said, "Let's do a set of 100 calls, 500 calls, 2,000 calls, whatever your team has the ability to actually analyze."
We will do them, your team will do them.
Let's compare them.
Got it.
Like a bake-off.
It's a, like, how would your QA team look at them?
And what we found was, for benefits verification calls, just as an example, we were different 25% of the time.
Oh, interesting.
And what was the nature of those differences?
Well, at first we didn't know, and they were like, "Ah, you're wrong 25% of the time."
And we said, "Well, how about we do it, the AI call twice?"
And we found that we were different 25% of the time.
So, you call the same payer, yeah, twice for the same patient, and you will get different answers 25% of the time because it's a human on the other side that may have opened the wrong PDF.
Okay?
So you unearth just like inherent error in the in the system, in the system that we wouldn't have known.
And so we built a knowledge graph based on all the calls that we do to know what right looks like so that now our AI agents, if they hear something that seems wrong, we'll push back and say, can you check that again?
And we find 70 to 80% of time when we push back.
I feel like you should publish these stats.
And this is the reality, and you talk to the payers, the PBMs, or any, any group, everyone knows this, that's why they make multiple calls, they, uh, don't always believe it, they really push, they ask for escalations when you think about time savings.
It's the fact that you don't have to do the same task multiple times.
It's the fact that in real time you're doing QA.
It's a win for everybody.
So that's how we prove to them that what we were doing was, was real and good.
And then you get deployed.
Come the world of chat GPT.
Everyone's like, that's all you can do?
Can't you also do X, Y, and Z, and you can, you know, build, build the world on top of it?
And now it's a race to how much more can you do faster, cuz my team wants it.
Mhm.
And then, you know, that was 2022, 2023.
As I think about this year, I think there's a lot of breaks being put, uh, because there's too many AI vendors, or everybody is an AI vendor, and no large entity, I, I think we, we support something like 44 or 45% of the Fortune 50.
We support the largest entities, and all of them are being inundated by every vendor saying we're an AI vendor.
So, those chief AI officers, they're setting up AI review boards, machine learning review boards, uh, that have great intentions.
They want to make sure they're not introducing biases to the system.
They want to make sure that they are not, uh, losing ownership of their data.
There's a lot of these, uh, checklists that are being put into place, but we're still at the first innings.
A lot of them are thinking about this as one size fits all for every problem that's out there.
Yeah.
Are you finding that people are still viewing your product as a technology purchase?
Essentially, you are kind of augmenting their staff in many ways, and obviously, as we know, labor budgets tend to be much larger in Healthcare.
Where are you getting slotted?
We've never been part of the technology budget because from the very beginning we were selling to the operations leaders.
Um, technology had IT teams had to sign off and do the integrations, but it was a way of, the operations team saying, how can we support more, and especially as we went through COVID, there was a huge shortage, and there continues to be a huge shortage.
And so we've become part of that operational muscles of our customers.
There's a flurry of activity called a blizzard that happens in the first three to four weeks of January where everyone wants to make sure their patients are still active, still eligible, still fully covered.
So everyone just calls the payers.
So the payers staff up in October and November, do test calls in December so they can support incoming calls in January.
On the provider side, everyone hires up in September, October, November.
And so time after time when folks take us in, well, they don't have to have three months of just hiring and staffing and people being paid for ramp up to do three to four weeks of work.
They can use technology in the way it's supposed to be in an elastic, scalable way.
That, that example is absolutely the case.
The second, we've seen a lot of attrition in the Healthcare workforce in the last few years, and we've been able to just backfill that, that group, and we've been able to, for, for some of our customers, I think the most exciting, and this is the most exciting part, is we can help drive revenue as they grow without their teams having to worry about, uh, to, to worry about where are they going to find workers in a, in a time of shortage.
Specialty pharmacies are growing at a faster pace than ever before.
Many of the largest ones are our customers, and every year the biggest ask they have of the CFO is more headcount, and now they're saying, I don't need as much new headcount.
Yeah, that's amazing.
So you're kind of like leaning, there's a lot of, you know, fearful talk about replacing jobs and all that, but what you're saying is you're basically that there's enough surface area where you're focused on things that we just couldn't even hire enough humans to do things that, um, where there's natural, you know, kind of churn, let's call it, in the workforce, and no need to kind of backfill one-to-one, and then, you know, shifting, you mentioned earlier, like, shifting the humans to actually be able to work on more patient-facing things, on higher-value things that only humans are qualified to do, or, or, you know, many RCM groups, uh, spend more than half their day waiting on hold.
Yeah.
Right.
Every claim is bespoke.
Uh, that those workflows, we, we believe are, you know, when you can get the data digitally, great, through APIs is great.
But the conversations actually get pretty complex.
It's like, hey, you sent me a check for $15.85.
It was supposed to be $150.85.
Um, why was that?

Maybe just like a market landscape perspective question here.
Like there seems to be centers of gravity forming around sort of the killer apps, right, with Healthcare AI.
You guys are working on one version of it.
You have things like AI scribes that are more, you know, provider facing.
You have a lot of these sort of non-voice, you kind of like autonomous, almost like the next generation RPA type tools.
Um, how do you see all of those things either converging or diverging over time?
Like do you think each of those actually end up being completely separate markets that don't overlap at all, or do you actually see, um, because of the innovations on the technology side, it being easier for a singular company to become almost like a super app platform across multiple use cases?
Yeah, I think this is an open question whether you ask the startups in the space, whether you ask the EHRs, the epics, the Cerners or the Salesforces, I think everyone wants to imagine themselves being the orchestration layer of all these agents that come together, right?
So today, as we're at the infancy of this revolution, if you will, everyone's building a set of agents.
We're building a set of data exchange agents.
Some clinical, some administrative, some voice, some electronic, others are building scribing agents, but the layer underneath it, that last mile integration problem that we talked about, it's still to be determined who ends up owning that layer.
And I think the agent companies are going to try to go down, the platform companies are going to try to go up.
And it's going to be interesting to see how that plays out over the next couple of years.
Yeah, I think it's a great thing that there is like real market competition here that's driving the bar up on the caliber of the products that we're seeing out there and the talent.

The talent, the I mean just the amount of spend that is being absorbed by the system.

I think healthcare data is still pretty desperate.
Um, and that means that there's a lack of context.
In some cases, the data is missing.
In some cases, it's in a thousand different places.

Uh, a good example of something that you know as I talk to some of our partners is everyone sees the potential of integrating social determinants of health data, but it's missing 80% of the time.
